monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: In the western part (of the plain), if somebody had killed (a man), his blood was wanted (i.e. e has brought blood feud upon himself). This also happened upon us. It also happened upon us. When my grandfather Aḥmad al-Maḥmūd, the father of Ǧōšāw, killed a man in (the village of) Mqayyre. I want to tell you the story; (I’ll tell you) the issue again from the beginning.
They were playing the game ḥūṛa. You may not know about the ḥūṛa. I have not seen it either, but they were talking about it. As for the ḥūṛa, they pull out the root of a tree.
They pull it out and make a kind of ball out of it. They have sticks in their hands and they make ‘castles’ (using stones). Then they start hitting each other in the ‘castles’.
Like that they are throwing it with bats, we call it qōl; it’s like baseball. When they were playing ḥūṛa a man from the Ǧumēle tribe insulted my grandfather.
(My grandfather) was a good ḥūṛa-player; he played it well. No one could beat him, no one could defeat him. It is said that this one had insulted him.

He said, “Dude, stand still! I am coming to you. Wait for me! I am coming to you now. I will come and fuck your mother’s hole!” It is said that this one (viz. his grandfather) went inside and brought a gun.

He put the gun on him and hit him. He shot him and a sparrow down on the ground, him and the sparrow. It is said that he went back home and said Well, I do not remember my grandmother’s name anymore – Her name was Čarxāwiyye – I do not know, Zakwa, I do not know what (her name) was.
He said to her, “Take the children and run away immediately! Right away! To Qōrān!” (The fields of the village of) Qōrān border to Mqayyre. And they were in Mqayyre.
It is said that they left; they left because of the Ǧumēle as they had already gathered with guns in their hands. They came to shoot my grandfather.
He lay on his front levelling on them and shot a bullet. They all hid themselves and said, “This man’s blood is wanted.
Be aware, he can shoot you all right away.” Anyways, they had arrived in Qōrān. In Qōrān, Ḥlayyil al-Ḥamze was the tribe’s leader, the leader of the Bani ʕIǧil tribe at that time.

“What did you do?” He said, “Well, our blood is wanted” He took them under his protection for the sake of my grandfather Bōzaw and my grandfather No! My grandfather Barha al-Dugmān and my grandfather Ǧōšaw. He took them under his protection.

He said, “My blood is wanted. Solve this matter!” They gathered to do something. They said, “Let him move away from here! Let him go into exile!” “Where should he move to?” “He must move to the Bani Mḥimmad tribe, to the west.

He must move to the Bani Mḥimmad tribe, to the west.” They were banished for seven years; they were driven out into the west for seven years. But it is said that their house, let’s say, their ghee, their cattle, their goats. It is said that they got in with daggers.

They killed their cow; they slashed its belly and threw it on the field. They threw its guts on the ground and left it. The Ǧumēle came to his property and due to a blood boiling moment they attacked their cattle and pillaged his whole house.
He went for seven years into exile. However, one day he had the right to return to his place. One day then, some of the men of thingy, the relative of Aḥmad al-ʕAddād.
They were hunting in Ḥarrān. They were hunting thingy, foxes. It is said that they were all going out to hunt. In the past, they used to have headbands.
Headbands. Didn’t they put it on their heads? The headbands. It is said that he tightened his headdress like the ears of a fox. In this way.

The hare? – The fox. Like the ears of a fox. He had put like a pointy ending on his head. It is said that there was this pointy ending (on his headdress) when he was going to the privy to defecate; like going to the toilet.
It is said that he went to the privy in the open field. When he was sitting next to a rock, his friend saw something like ears going up and down. It was at dawn and it was not yet light.

He aimed the gun at him and hit him. Lo and behold, he shot him down to the ground. He went to him and saw that it was his friend. He returned from there running and said, “I put blood on me.” He said, “I killed the so-and-so.” The one, whom he had killed was actually our relative, he was our relative; he was also from the Bani ʕIǧil.

They gathered for a meeting and said, “How, how can we make it happen? How can we reconcile them with each other?” Someone said, “Bōzaw and those from Aḥmad al-Maḥmūd whose blood were wanted, were banished for seven years. So, he must be banished for seven years too.”
And everyone who stays on his place, every tribe must pay the bloodwit for a man. The Bani ʕIǧil tribe must pay for the ʕIǧli and the Ǧumēle must pay for the Ǧumeyli.

Everyone who stays on his land. How Bōzaw’s son had been banished for seven years, you also must be banished for seven years.” In former times, whenever there was a blood feud, the issue would be like this. If the one in the west killed one in the west, he had to be banished to the east.

I mean they would take him to the east. They would hide him and would not hand him over to anyone. And the one in the west also would not hand over the one who came from the east. He would not let him go. So they used to banish (people) among them.
Well, in former times, the east and the west (of the Plain of Harran) were always like that. Only the road would separate them. They used to fight each other; they also used to fight each other.
